mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Essays on Policy and Women's Health

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation contains three studies which focus on how health policies affect women. The second chapter examines how public health policies can lead to unintended effects that undermine their efficacy. Beginning in the mid-1930s, most states enacted policies requiring serological syphilis tests prior to receiving a marriage license. Using novel county-level health statistics, I find no evidence suggesting that the policies were effective at reducing the prevalence of sexually transmitted infections. The serological testing policies had two unintended consequences that potentially reduced their effectiveness. First, the increased cost of marriage deterred marriage for young couples. Using microdata from the U.S. Census, I find that these policies delayed marriage and fertility and increased female educational attainment and employment. Second, marriage licenses decreased in counties with pre-marital testing policies and increased in bordering counties, suggesting that couples traveled to marry in less restrictive states. Chapters 3 and 4 address the effects of professional guidelines on health decisions. In 2014, to address concerns of overtreatment, a panel of experts released new guidelines on the amount of normal tissue to be excised around a tumor in breast conserving surgery (BCS) for early-stage cancers. In a differences-in-differences set-up utilizing the variation in timing of the guidelines and clinical stage at diagnosis, I find that women with stage 1 and stage 2 breast cancer receive fewer re-excision surgeries following initial BCS and are less likely to receive mastectomy after the guidelines relative to women with more advanced disease. The decrease in mastectomy is driven by patients who would have gone on to receive further reconstructive surgery. In Chapter 4, I study the effects of changes to cervical cancer screening guidelines recommending screening begin at age 21 rather than age 18. The guidelines significantly decreased the probability young women report having ever been screened relative to women over the age of 21. The delay in recommended screening also delayed receipt of other services from specialist providers. For example, I find suggestive evidence that the guidelines decreased the probability of using long acting reversible contraceptives for young women and increased the use of contraceptive methods with higher typical use failure rates.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Economics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Carl Kitchens, Professor Directing Dissertation; Irene Padavic, University Representative; Luke Rodgers, Committee Member; Shawn Kantor, Committee Member.
